Title: Every subsequence of $x_n$ has a further subsequence which converges to $x$. Then the sequence $x_n$ converges to $x$.
Content:
Is the following true? Let $x_n$ be a sequence with the following property: Every subsequence of $x_n$ has a
further subsequence which converges to $x$. Then the sequence $x_n$ converges to $x$. I guess that it is true but I am not sure how to prove this.
AcceptedAnswer: True. If not, there exists an $\epsilon > 0$, such that for all $k$, there exists an $n_k > k$ satisfying $|x_{n_k}−x| \ge \epsilon$ since if there is some $k$ which doesn't have such $n_k$, then we can take it as $N$, so $x_n$ converges to $x$. The subsequence $x_{n_{k}}$ does not have any subsequence converging to $x$.

But if all those terms are outside the epsilon neighborhood, how can a subsequence of them converge to \( x \)? That seems contradictory. Because if a subsequence converges to \( x \), eventually all its terms must lie within any given epsilon neighborhood of \( x \). Wait, maybe this is the key. Suppose, for contradiction, that \( x_n \) does not converge to \( x \). Then there exists an epsilon > 0 such that for infinitely many n, \( |x_n - x| \geq \epsilon \). But all terms of \( x_{n_k} \) are at least epsilon away from \( x \), so any subsequence of it would also have terms at least epsilon away. Hence, such a sub-subsequence cannot converge to \( x \), which contradicts the given condition. Therefore, our initial assumption that \( x_n \) does not converge to \( x \) must be false. Thus, \( x_n \) converges to \( x \).

So taking that subsequence, we can't have a sub-subsequence converging to \( x \), which violates the problem's condition. Therefore, such a subsequence can't exist, meaning the original sequence must converge.

Another way to think about it is using the concept of limit points. If every subsequence has a further subsequence converging to \( x \), then \( x \) is the only limit point of the original sequence. If the sequence doesn't converge, it must have more than one limit point or oscillate, but in this case, every subsequence's limit is \( x \), so the sequence must converge to \( x \).

Alternatively, using the definition of closure in topology, but maybe that's overcomplicating.
